abstract: On Monday night, a raft of Korean culture and tourism groups held a dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, preceded by a pageant in the great hall.
snippet: On Monday night, a raft of Korean culture and tourism groups held a dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, preceded by a pageant in the great hall.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, a raft of Korean culture and tourism groups held a dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, preceded by a pageant in the great hall (Korean fashion, as well as food, was being celebrated). The banquet reflected the cuisine of the country's imperial court in the Chosun dynasty, which lasted from about 1400 to 1900. Han Bok-ryeo, the nation's official "master chef," was brought in to oversee the serving of kalbi-jjim (braised beef), kimchi, ssam (rolls), mushrooms, and root vegetables like radishes and carrots - enhanced with aromatics like baby ginseng, pine nuts, dried seaweed and dried red chile. Even tarakjuk, soft rice porridge traditionally served to the emperor at dawn, appeared as a first course, sprinkled with chives.

headline.main: Korea's 'Master Chef' Prepares a Banquet at the Met
